article.headline: Washington State 61, USC 53
article.story: PULLMAN, Wash. (AP) -- Washington State beat Southern California for the fourth straight time Saturday afternoon, but that didn't stop Cougars' coach Dick Bennett from dressing down his players before they had a chance to undress after the game. "They outplayed us," Bennett said after his lecture to Cougar players following the 61-53 victory at Friel Court. "I was disappointed in the way we played almost from start to finish." Despite Bennett's complaints, the Cougars led almost all the way, evened their overall record at 10-10 and improved to 5-6 in the Pacific-10 Conference. The Cougars shot better than 50 percent from the field for just the second time all year, showed rare balance by having four players score in double figures, and held the Trojans (9-13, 2-9) to their second-lowest point total of the season. Jeff Varem, Thomas Kelati and Robbie Cowgill each scored 11 points for the Cougars, and Chris Schlatter finished with 10. Freshman Derrick Low added eight points and a season-high eight assists, and Varem led all players with nine rebounds and a career-high five steals. The Cougars, one of the worst shooting teams in the nation at 39.7 percent, nailed 55.3 percent of their shots. Washington State's only better effort this season (57.4) came in a 69-52 win at Southern Cal on Jan. 8. Gabriel Pruitt led Southern Cal with 10. The Trojans shot just 41.2 percent, and their two lowest point totals of the season have come against Washington State's touted defense. However, Bennett said the Trojans "executed their game plan better than us" and "carved us up" with their penetration on offense. Southern Cal outrebounded the Cougars 31-25. "We had zero offensive rebounds. Zero," said Bennett, who said that's a first for one of his teams in 27 years of college coaching. "That pretty much indicates how aggressive and tough-minded we were." "We weren't too pleased with our play," said Cowgill, a freshman who scored nine points in the first nine minutes before running into foul trouble and eventually fouling out. "We made a lot of mistakes." The Cougars led 31-25 at the half, but Southern Cal tied the game at 49 on Nick Young's short jumper with 4:57 left to play. Kelati snapped the tie and put Washington State ahead for good with 4:30 to go when he hit one of two free throws after Southern Cal coach Jim Saia was hit with a technical when he threw his jacket off in protest of a foul call against Gregg Guenther. Aware of the Pac-10s ban on public criticism of officials, Saia said, "I can't comment on officials. I just threw my coat off." Saia is interim coach until Tim Floyd takes over next season. He and Bennett were extremely animated and vocal in expressing their dissatisfaction with the officials throughout the game. "I've been in the league two years, and I don't understand the whistles," Bennett said. "I'm not going to say any more than that."

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
